Have you ever successfully started Ubuntu in "normal mode" (i.e., not low graphics mode)?
Then something has changed on your system lately -- you might have performed an upgrade, installed third party software, accidentally deleted some files...
Something has caused Ubuntu's graphics driver for your video card to fail, where it worked before.
Your computer "froze"? You mean everything, including the mouse cursor?
That's called a kernel panic.
When you experience a kernel panic, it's possible that you might lose data if the operating system has recently written to a file that hasn't been pushed out to disk.
If you installed updates using Update Manager shortly before the panic, it's possible that the updates were only partially committed, which might put the graphics driver in a bad state.
About how long have you been using this installation of Ubuntu?

Well, something _has_ certainly changed on your system to cause the graphics driver to go from a working state to a non working state. Without examining your configuration more closely, I can't tell you exactly what happened. But the kernel panic is indicative of possible data loss.
No. I'm saying that the software on your hard drive that operates your graphics card from Ubuntu's side is defective.
No, it's not. In fact, it's extremely possible.

If Ubuntu displays a pop-up saying that it's starting in low graphics mode, it is a deeper problem than simply setting the screen resolution. The system is loading a fallback driver; you're lucky you have a graphical display at all.
Do you need instructions to post your Xorg.0.conf file? It's not difficult, especially if you are logged into that computer right now.
